title: OpenAI, Amazon Sign $38 Billion Cloud Deal
description: In a monumental move that reshapes the artificial intelligence landscape, Amazon Web Services (AWS) announced Monday a seven-year, $38 billion strategic alliance with OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT. The agreement will make AWS the computing backbone behind OpenAI’s next generation of models — a deal that underscores the intensifying global race to control AI infrastructure. Amazon OpenAI $38B Deal cements AWS as the AI backbone powering ChatGPT and frontier model innovation.
content: In a monumental move that reshapes the artificial intelligence landscape, Amazon Web Services (AWS) announced Monday a seven-year, $38 billion strategic alliance with OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT. The agreement will make AWS the computing backbone ... [1417 chars]

title: Hippocratic AI valued at $3.5 billion in latest financing round
description: Hippocratic AI raised $126 million in its latest funding round led by Avenir Growth, it said on Monday, valuing the healthcare company at $3.5 billion and underscoring venture capital's strong interest towards artificial intelligence-integrated companies.
content: Nov 3 (Reuters) - Hippocratic AI raised $126 million in its latest funding round led by Avenir Growth, it said on Monday, valuing the healthcare company at $3.5 billion and underscoring venture capital's strong interest towards artificial intelligenc... [630 chars]

title: S&P 500 eyes 7,000 as November kicks off - can the market’s hottest month deliver again?
description: S&P 500 is racing into November eyeing 7,000 — and history says it just might do it. Since 1927, stocks have finished higher in nearly 60% of Novembers. Today, the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.6% as traders piled back into artificial intelligence stocks after a wave of major AI announcements. The S&P 500 added 0.2%. Amazon soared 4% on a $38 billion OpenAI deal. Nvidia climbed 2% as it expanded its UAE investment to $15.2 billion. Micron jumped 4%. AI stocks are leading the charge again. The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 added 0.2%. But the rallys getting narrow — more than 400 S&P 500 stocks fell Monday. Still, with 80% of Q3 earnings beating estimates, bulls see room to run.
content:
